repnme.cdata!:
Afghanistan - Public Administration
            Capacity Building Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Public Administration
            Capacity Building Project (PACBP) for Afghanistan were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was substantial, Bank performance was satisfactory,
            and Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: lack of proper knowledge of bidding
            documents among the domestic bidders restricted their
            ability to submit the bids in proper format and with
            requisite information/documents. In light of this
            shortcoming, it is necessary to improve their knowledge of
            bidding documents. Motivation to build capacity becomes
            limited when consultants are performing functions in the
            absence of civil servants. Consulting firms offer limited
            career path to local staff, which exacerbates this problem.
            Permanent cadre of personnel in the line ministries is
            essential, as lack of continuity of personnel adversely
            affects retention of knowledge. Any decision on legal
            framework should be taken after consultation with all major
            stakeholders as the Procurement Law, 2008 was enacted in
            July 2008 without consulting major donor and that resulted
            in to delays and amendments to the Law. Audit and financial
            management powers rely on strong integrated legislative
            bases to work well. The PACBP included plans for better
            legislation but did not control the legal drafting
            development processes. Legislation developments were
            assisted by consultative processes that included all
            relevant players. Related legislation such as finance and
            audit could best be pushed through together if possible. To
            overcome the institutional rivalries and resistances,
            development partner mediation and support should be heavily
            emphasized and institutional rigidities dealt with as best
            as possible within the practicalities of the other factors
            at play.

repnme.cdata!:
Afghanistan - Public Administration
            Capacity Building : Proposed Project Restructuring and
            Amendment to the Credit Agreements

abstracts.cdata!:
The Afghanistan Public Administration
            Capacity Building Project aims to enhance the performance of
            public sector procurement, financial management, and
            accountability systems which will contribute to a more
            effective, transparent, and accountable state. This Project
            Paper seeks the approval of the Executive Directors to
            introduce the following changes in the Afghanistan, Public
            Administration Capacity Building Project and any
            accompanying amendments to the project's legal
            documents. The proposed changes would include: (i) amending
            the Project Development Objective (PDO) to more accurately
            reflect the original intent of the Government of Afghanistan
            and donors, and to assure a high level of integrity in the
            management of public sector resources; and (ii) reducing the
            scope of training activities intended to contribute to
            building internal Ministry of Finance and line-ministry capacity.

repnme.cdata!:
Afghanistan - Public Administration
            Capacity Building Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Administration Capacity
            Building Project for Afghanistan aims to assist the
            authorities in developing the capacity to manage public
            expenditures in an effective, transparent, and accountable
            manner in order to achieve satisfactory and sustainable
            development outcomes in Afghanistan. The project will have a
            particular focus on enhancing the performance of public
            sector procurement, financial management, and accountability
            systems. Success in meeting the project's objective
            will be measured by: establishment and implementation of
            sound regulatory and control frameworks for budget execution
            and fiscal reporting, and public sector procurement; further
            development of core systems for budget execution, government
            accounting, and internal and external audits; development of
            HR to effectively manage and operate these critical systems;
            and operational performance (technical efficiency) of the
            fiduciary management functions.
